Award.AwardTitle: SaTC: CORE: Small: Collaborative: CPS ACTS: Orchestrating CPS with Action Blocks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The integration of computation, communication and sensing technologies into our transportation, power grid, healthcare, and manufacturing systems presents unprecedented challenges in ensuring the security and safety of these systems. Cyber attacks on such systems cross from the cyber realm into the physical world, and we must deal with new attack trends that may cause vehicles to veer off the road, manipulate devices responsible for power generation, distribution and consumption, and exploit robotic/drone systems for malicious activities. This project develops methodologies that ensure the resiliency of such systems through developing defense strategies in response to the attack strategies available to the adversary.

To ensure the resiliency of Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) against cyber attacks, this project explores the use of a game-theoretic framework to orchestrate the CPS with the proper combination and configuration of action blocks. This project posits that action blocks can be used to ensure the integrity of a system's control and measurement signals by checking the signals' values and manipulating these values in manners devised to detect attacks. This exploratory effort will develop initial game theoretic models and accompanying reinforcement learning techniques to investigate possible defense strategies that rely on mixtures of action blocks, focusing on the generalizability, implementability, and scalability of the approach. This project lays the ground work for a more extensive open library of action blocks in which CPS developers may not only contribute blocks but also invoke the resulting methods to assemble potent defense strategies for their systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our everyday environments contain myriad embedded systems that allow us to control various aspects of our environments (or to have those aspects controlled automatically on our behalf). Ensuring these control systems are safe, secure, and robust is essential to building the human users' trust in their actions. Prior to this project, our work had focused on validating that the software controlling a cyber-physical system behaved as expected, from a functional perspective. This project looked at whether, in addition to performing the correct function, the non-functional properties, e.g., security and robustness could be checked in a similar way. We developed "blocks" that could be inserted in a software/hardware system that could detect (and correct!) anomalies in the system behavior that has the potential to lead to dangerous or unexpected conditions.

One difficulty we uncovered in checking and correcting these embedded systems is in the distribution of the components of the system, which communicate using various wireless communication technologies. Ensuring that the system is functioning correctly is ensuring that the correct devices are integrated into a system's control flow loop. Leveraging the incorrect devices, whether because of a malicious attacker manipulating the data flow or because of noise and uncertainty in the environment, can lead to a lack of robustness, integrity, and, potentially, physical security or safety. Within this project, we therefore made strides to support future cyber physical systems by ensuring the integration of the correct wireless components in a control-flow loop that includes a human user.

Finally, we also started to investigate the ways in which similar principles could be applied to checking and correcting the behavior of systems that share private, personal data.
